Ill fated tree! — Ah little did I ween</br>My frail and fading Life of longer date</br>Than thy firm Root, fair Stem and Branches sheen</br>That on the lingering sun beam smil'd so late!</br>Ah verse, — all powerless to postpone thy Fate.—</br>But in this Age Verse ill can intervene</br>Against Destruction's fang: — or ruthless War</br>The Realms of Verse and Arts ere this had ceas'd to tear.

Fallen art thou at once! — whom fiercest blast</br>Harm'd not, nor Winter's icy bolt could rive,</br>Man, more destructive than all storms, hath cast</br>To Earth! — for Ages thus dost thou survive?</br>Presumptuous Hope, that trusts aught here shall last!—</br>Not e'en a shatter'd Trunk where Bees might hive</br>Is left, where late thou didst so fair aspire;</br>Nor Branch, on which to hang the unavailing Lyre!

Nor Zephyr's breath, nor dew of vernal Heaven</br>Shall wake thee now; — whom, all up-rotted, tore</br>The cruel Axe! — to thee henceforth are even</br>"All seasons and their Change!" — Thee I deplore;</br>And in thy imag'd ruin muse on more</br>Which Man hath still to feel: — to Man is given</br>To see what wins the heart and charms the eyes,</br>Marks and adorns Life's Road, Death's unexpected Prize.</br>
